title: Understanding Fork Bomb - The Process Explosion

parts.explanation: Function calls itself and pipes to itself
Execute the function to start the chain reaction

what_happens.step: First process spawns 2 copies of itself
Hundreds of processes consuming CPU and memory
Thousands of processes - system becomes unresponsive
System runs out of process slots - can't start new programs
System completely frozen - keyboard/mouse don't respond
Only option: Hard reboot (hold power button)

real_world_impact: A fork bomb creates an exponential explosion of processes that consume all system resources in seconds. Your computer will freeze completely, and you'll have no choice but to force a hard reboot. Any unsaved work is lost. It's called a 'bomb' for a reason.
prevention_tips: Never run commands you don't understand, especially cryptic ones
Set process limits with 'ulimit -u' to prevent fork bombs
Modern systems have protections, but they're not foolproof
If you see ':(){' or similar patterns, it's likely a fork bomb
Learn to recognize dangerous patterns before running them
Use virtual machines for testing suspicious commands
